case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City I v. the assessee

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 323 of 1962 filed by Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City I.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 323 of 196. Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 25, 1958, of the Bombay High Court in I.T.R. No. 3 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated September 25, 1958, of Bombay High Court in I.T.R. No. 3 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 25, 1958, of the Bombay High Court in I.T.R. No. 3 of 1958. N. Rajagopal Sastri and D. Gupta, for the appellant.

facts.text: Assessee assessed to income-tax as individual for assessment year 1954-55.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee, who is the respondent before us, was assessed to income-tax as an individual in respect of his income for the assessment year 1954-55.

facts.text: Taxing authorities included Rs. 410/- in assessee's total income for 1954-55.

anchor.surface_text: The taxing authorities included in the assessees total income for the year to sums, namely, a sum of Rs. 410/- and a sum of Rs. 14,170/-.

facts.text: Taxing authorities included Rs. 14,170/- in assessee's total income for 1954-55.

anchor.surface_text: The taxing authorities included in the assessees total income for the year to sums, namely, a sum of Rs. 410/- and a sum of Rs. 14,170/-.

facts.text: Assessee created trust on January 12, 1953, for Rs. 25,000/- with trustees Central Bank Executor Trustee Co., assessee, his wife and brother.

anchor.surface_text: On January 12, 1953 the assessee created a trust in respect of a sum of Rs, 25,000/-, the trustees whereof were the Central Bank Executor Trustee Co., the assessee himself his wife and brother.

facts.text: Trust scheme: interest on Rs. 25,000/- accumulated and added to corpus until daughter Chandrika attains 18 on February 1, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of the trust-deed was that the said sum of Rs. 25,000/- was set apart by the assessee and it was provided that the interest on that amount should be accumulated and added to the companypus and a minor daughter of the assessee, named Chandrika, was to receive the income from the companypus increased by the addition of interest, when she attained the age of 18 on February 1, 1959.

facts.text: Income from 1953 trust fund Rs. 410/- in relevant account year.

anchor.surface_text: The income derived from the said trust fund amounted to Rs. 410/- in the relevant account year and the taxing authorities included this amount in the total income of the assessee,

facts.text: Assessee's father created trust on December 1, 1941, shares and Rs. 30,000/- for four sons including assessee.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the second sum of Rs. 14,170/- it appears that on December 1, 1941, the assessees father had created a trust in respect of some shares and a cash sum of Rs. 30,000/- for the benefit of his four sons including the assessee.

facts.text: Trustees of 1941 trust: Central Bank Executor and Trustee Co. Ltd., assessee, one other person.

anchor.surface_text: The trustees were the Central Bank Executor and Trustee Co. Ltd., the assessee himself and one other person.

facts.text: 1941 trust: trustees to pay net interest and income to assessee for maintenance of himself, wife, children till his death.

anchor.surface_text: The said trustees were to hold the trust funds upon trust to pay the net interest and income thereof to the assessee for the maintenance of himself and his wife and for the maintenance, education and benefit of all his children till his death.

facts.text: Income from 1941 trust Rs. 14,170/- accrued to assessee in relevant account year.

anchor.surface_text: The sum of Rs. 14,170/-. it was stated, accrued as income in the hands of the assessee in the relevant account year from the said trust funds.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal upheld inclusion of both sums in assessee's income.

anchor.surface_text: The view of the taxing authorities and the Income- tax Appellate Tribunal was that under the aforesaid provision of the trust deed the assessee was the sole beneficiary

facts.text: Tribunal stated case to High Court on April 24, 1957 order under s.66(1).

anchor.surface_text: On being satisfied that these questions of law arose out of the order of the Tribunal dated April 24, 1957, the Tribunal stated a case under s. 66 1  of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: High Court answered both questions in favor of assessee on September 25, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered both the questions in favour of the assessee by its judgment and order dated September 25, 1958.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate of fitness under s.66A(2).

anchor.surface_text: There after the High Court granted a certificate of fitness under s. 66A 2  of the Income-tax Act and, as we have already stated, the present appeal has been brought

facts.text: Chandrika was minor in relevant year, attained 18 on Feb 1, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Now, in the relevant year of account Chandrika was still a minor and under the terms of the trust deed she had numberright to the trust income number any beneficial interest therein

facts.text: During Chandrika's minority, trust income accumulated and added to corpus, no right or benefit to her.

anchor.surface_text: she companyld neither receive number enjoy the income. She did number derive any benefit whatsoever from the trust funds during her minority and even after she attained majority, she did number have any right to the trust income which arose during her minority

facts.text: Assessee contention: Rs.410/- not includible as Chandrika had no right or interest in relevant year.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the assessee the companytention was that the sum of Rs. 410/- aforesaid was number liable to be included in the total income of the assessee inasmuch as Chandrika, the minor daughter of the assessee, had numberright to the income

facts.text: Assessee contention: Rs.14,170/- not includible as assessee not sole beneficiary, held in trust for wife and children.

anchor.surface_text: As to the sum of Rs. 14,170/- the case of the assessee was that it should number be included in his total income as the sole beneficiary, because the beneficiaries under the trust settlement were number only the assessee but his wife and children as well.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered January 31, 1962 by K. DAS, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. January 31. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS, J.-The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City I, has preferred this appeal to this Court

facts.text: Clause 7 of 1941 trust deed: trustees to pay income to assessee for maintenance of himself, wife, children till death.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant clause of the trust deed of December 1, 1941 is cl. 7 which reads as follows The trustees shall hold and stand possessed of the Trust Fund mentioned in the second Schedule hereto and the accumulations thereof referred to in clause 3 thereof upon Trust to pay the net interest and income thereof to the Settlers son MANILAL for the maintenance of himself, his wife and for the maintenance, education and benefit of all his children till his death.

facts.text: Court finding: Clause 7 creates trust in favor of assessee, wife, children; assessee is trustee, not sole beneficiary.

anchor.surface_text: We are in agreement with the High Court that the direction companytained in cl. 7 created a trust in favour of the assessee, his wife and children. The expression for the maintenance of himself and his wife and for the maintenance, education and benefit of all his children is number indicative of a mere desire or hope.

issues.text: The question before us is whether under this clause the income received by the assessee is impressed with a trust in favour of himself, his wife and children to whom he is accountable as a trustee for the amount received.

anchor.surface_text: The question before us is whether under this clause the income received by the assessee is impressed with a trust in favour of himself, his wife and children to whom he is accountable as a trustee for the amount received.

issues.text: In other words, the question is whether the trust deed of December 1, 1941, created two trusts, the one requiring the trustees to pay the income from the trusts funds to the assessee and the second requiring the assessee to spend the income for the maintenance of himself and his wife and for the maintenance, education and benefit of his children.

anchor.surface_text: In other words, the question is whether the trust deed of December 1, 1941, created two trusts, the one requiring the trustees to pay the income from the trusts funds to the assessee and the second requiring the assessee to spend the income for the maintenance of himself and his wife and for the maintenance, education and benefit of his children.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of s.16(3)(a) and (b) requires actual benefit, accrual, or interest to minor child in relevant accounting year; strict construction of artificial tax avoidance provision; tax assessed on yearly basis per ss.4(1) and 2(15)

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, when cl. b of sub-s. 3 of s. 16 talks of benefit of the minor child it refers to benefit which arises or accrues to the minor in the year of account.

precedents.citation: In re. Booth, Booth v. Booth 1

anchor.surface_text: In re. Booth, Booth v. Booth 1 a testator gave the residue of his estate to his executors, on trust, to pay to his wife or permit her to receive the annual income thereof during her life, for her use and benefit and for the maintenance and education of my children. It was held that the wife took the income subject to a trust for the maintenance and education of the children. A similar view was expressed in Raikes Ward 1 and Woods v. Woods 2 On behalf of the appellant our attention was drawn to s. 8 of the Indian Trusts Act, 1882 II of 1882 which states that the subject matter of a trust must be property transferable to the beneficiary and it must number be merely beneficial interest under a subsisting trust.

precedents.case_name: In re Booth, Booth v Booth
precedents.cited_proposition: direction to apply income for maintenance and education of children creates a binding trust on the recipient
precedents.cited_holding: the wife took the income subject to a trust for the maintenance and education of the children

anchor.surface_text: Raikes Ward 1 and Woods v. Woods 2 On behalf of the appellant our attention was drawn to s. 8 of the Indian Trusts Act, 1882 II of 1882 which states that the subject matter of a trust must be property transferable to the beneficiary and it must number be merely beneficial interest under a subsisting trust. It is companytended that the assessee held a beneficial interest in the income from the trust funds under the trust deed of December 1, 1941, and in respect of beneficial interest another trust companyld number be created in favour of himself, his wife and children. We think that this argument proceeds on a misconception. The assessee did number create a second trust in respect of the beneficial interest which he held under the trust deed of December 1, 1914.

precedents.cited_proposition: direction to apply income for maintenance and education of children creates a binding trust

anchor.surface_text: Woods v. Woods 2 On behalf of the appellant our attention was drawn to s. 8 of the Indian Trusts Act, 1882 II of 1882 which states that the subject matter of a trust must be property transferable to the beneficiary and it must number be merely beneficial interest under a subsisting trust. It is companytended that the assessee held a beneficial interest in the income from the trust funds under the trust deed of December 1, 1941, and in respect of beneficial interest another trust companyld number be created in favour of himself, his wife and children. We think that this argument proceeds on a misconception. The assessee did number create a second trust in respect of the beneficial interest which he held under the trust deed of December 1, 1914. The assessee father created two trusts by that trust deed, one requiring the trustees to pay the trust income to the assessee and the other requiring the assessee, who was himself a trustee, to spend the income for the maintenance, education and benefit of his children.

precedents.cited_proposition: direction to apply income for maintenance and education of children creates a binding trust

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Rajagopal Sastri made it clear that the intention of the Department was to include the sum in the total income of the assessee in order to levy and charge super-tax on him. This, we do number think, the Department was entitled to do. In respect of the sum of Rs. 14,170/- the assessee was a trustee, within the meaning of s. 41 of the Income-tax Act, appointed under a trust declared by a duly executed instrument in writing and as such trustee he had the right to contend that his assessment in respect of the money received by him number as a beneficiary but as a trustee companyld only be made under the first proviso to s. 41 1 . We have, therefore, come to the conclusion that on the second question also the answer given by the High Court was correct.
